snippet: Judith Scott, who had Down syndrome and no formal training or education to speak of, built a global reputation with string and sticks.
abstract: Lawrence Downes Editorial Observer column praises work of artist Judith Scott, whose retrospective is currently on view at the Brooklyn Museum; observes Scott has achieved international renown despite fact that she has Down syndrome, cannot hear or speak, and has had no formal training; notes Scott's dignity through achievement is too often the exception for people with Down syndrome, whom society prefers to infantilize and ignore.
lead_paragraph: Judith Scott, who had Down syndrome and no formal training or education to speak of, built a global reputation with string and sticks.

headline.print_headline: An Artist Who Wrapped and Bound Her Work, and Then Broke Free
